## Functions to deprecate

These functions can be replaced with relevant functions `vim.fs`:

- [x] `path.`
	- [x] `dirname` https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3462 
	- [x] `sanitize` https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3464
	- [x] `exists` https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3471
	- [x] `is_dir` https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3475
	- [x] `is_file` https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3474
	- [x] escape_wildcards https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3510
    - [x] is_absolute https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3511
    - [x] join https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3520
    - [x] traverse_parents https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3525
    - [x] iterate_parents https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3522
    - [x] is_descendant https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3567 (not deprecated yet since replacement [vim.fs.relpath](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31790) is only available in neovim 0.11+)
    - [x] path_separator https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3521
- [x] `search_ancestors` #3767
- [ ] `root_pattern`
- [x] `find_git_ancestors` https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3507
- [x] `find_mercurial_ancestors` https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3476
- [x] `find_node_modules_ancestors` https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3477
- [x] `find_package_json_ancestors` https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3502

These functions can be made private in the next releases seeing as `user_commands` part has already been signaled for eventual deprecation:

- [x] `parse_user_command_options`
- [x] `create_module_commands`


## Proposal

1. Soft-deprecate after release of `nvim 0.8` + stabilization period. 
2. Internally redirect the calls to `vim.fs`.
3. Replace the functions inside `configs/[server].lua` wherever relevant
4. CI lints usage of banned/deprecated `util` functions. https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3462
5. Provide examples/docs that use the recommended functions

comment_data.body: @ranjithshegde this would still be a welcome change, if you are keen
there are some external compatibility issues. those functions not only used  in our repo.. so  I am a little worried about the issues that may arise from the changes.

> those functions not only used in our repo.

Where are they used? lspconfig was never intended to be a platform. It's intended to be data-only. And we need to move towards that. This is the way we will be able to improve quality and improve maintainability of these configs.

I knwo and agree your thought..but it used in some other plugins or user config .just a quick search you will see 
https://github.com/search?q=lspconfig.util&type=code&p=3

We don't necessarily need to remove `lspconfig.util.root_pattern`, we can start by updating their implementations to use vim.fs and minimizing code where possible. And where possible, show a deprecation message that explains how to use `vim.fs` directly instead of e.g. `lspconfig.util.root_pattern`. And update all of the examples in lspconfig docs to use `vim.fs` directly, instead of `lspconfig.util`.

yes.. just worried that some util functions  like util.pathjoin etc  abused and cause incompatibility issues. So I have not refactored here. even we have `vim.fs` module.. not all user will read our help doc.

# Plan

> what general strategy is for removing lspconfig functions

we should keep the util stuff around to avoid breaking downstream. meanwhile, in this repo:

- CI should fail if any config uses a deprecated `util` function https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3462
- we should remove all docs that suggest a deprecated `util` function

once we have isolated most of `util` in that way, then we can think about when/how to fully remove them.

Since we don't actually test/run any of the lua configs in CI to my knowledge, the best we can hope for is to make a string search of changed lines on PRs and complain if the deprecated function is used.

The "Proposal" in the main description of this issue is updated and correct. To be clear:

- we don't need to remove anything on `util`, its interface can stay frozen for back-compat.
- *internally*, the implementation of `util` should *shrink* as we update it to use stdlib features of the minimum-supported Nvim version.
- as we bump the minimum required Nvim, we will add lint rules to the lspconfig CI which prevent configs from using `util` functions if the minimum supported Nvim (currently 0.9) has alternatives.

For example, `search_ancestors` currently doesn't use `vim.fs.parents` even though it has been available since Nvim 0.8 https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/blob/39f31e178466e4ed23c8ea6fddd5b7a4d9699398/lua/lspconfig/util.lua#L248

I'm not really a fan of the suggested deprecation strategy. It creates extra CI work and makes the process harder because we now need to have bookkeeping of which util functions we use ourselves and which util functions are there for public use. What was so wrong about the previous deprecation strategy that we need to invent a new one on the spot?

There was no previous deprecation strategy for nvim-lspconfig. The goal is to shrink nvim-lspconfig in order to make progress towards upstreaming it, while minimizing damage to user trust. 

Which part of the above plan, specifically, do you want to change, and how, specifically? (Other than the CI work, which is merely a way to reduce the code review burden of nvim-lspconfig, and something that will materialize depending on the whims of the people maintaining nvim-lspconfig: https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3462 .)
Ok I see what you mean from the discussion in https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3460

https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3460 is a good example of why removing `util.dirname` gains almost nothing. Keeping the skeleton around is low cost. Because we'll just freeze it once everything is upstreamed. And meanwhile, shrinking the actual implementation gives us a clear picture of which logic still doesn't have an upstream equivalent. The mere presence of `util.dirname` doesn't harm anything, though, yes, we will need to update something like `.github/ci/run_sanitizer.sh` to prevent future uses of `util.dirname` in configs.

As we hollow-out the guts of `util`, it will become almost empty. We can later decide whether we want to delete it entirely, and that can be done as one big "breaking" step instead of many incremental "breaking" steps.

> Which part of the above plan, specifically, do you want to change, and how, specifically?

The proposed strategy is alright I guess, it's just more safe/careful than my personal preference. And I like having one deprecation strategy over all our repos if possible to reduce the mental overhead of keeping track of different strategies.

But I can work with the strategy you outlined, it's not a dealbreaker and we can make progress like you said.

title: shrink `util` implementation by using upstream functions, avoid `util` in configs
